speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: SCENE III. The same. The Forum.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Enter seven or eight Citizens

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: Once, if he do require our voices, we ought not to deny him.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: We may, sir, if we will.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: We have power in ourselves to do it, but it is a

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: power that we have no power to do; for if he show us

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: his wounds and tell us his deeds, we are to put our

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: tongues into those wounds and speak for them; so, if

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: he tell us his noble deeds, we must also tell him

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: our noble acceptance of them. Ingratitude is

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: monstrous, and for the multitude to be ingrateful,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: were to make a monster of the multitude: of the

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: which we being members, should bring ourselves to be

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: monstrous members.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: And to make us no better thought of, a little help

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: will serve; for once we stood up about the corn, he

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: himself stuck not to call us the many-headed multitude.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: We have been called so of many; not that our heads

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: are some brown, some black, some auburn, some bald,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: but that our wits are so diversely coloured: and

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: truly I think if all our wits were to issue out of

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: one skull, they would fly east, west, north, south,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: and their consent of one direct way should be at

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: once to all the points o' the compass.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Think you so? Which way do you judge my wit would

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: fly?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Nay, your wit will not so soon out as another man's

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: will;'tis strongly wedged up in a block-head, but

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: if it were at liberty, 'twould, sure, southward.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Why that way?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: To lose itself in a fog, where being three parts

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: melted away with rotten dews, the fourth would return

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: for conscience sake, to help to get thee a wife.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: You are never without your tricks: you may, you may.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Are you all resolved to give your voices? But

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: that's no matter, the greater part carries it. I

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: say, if he would incline to the people, there was

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: never a worthier man.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Enter CORIOLANUS in a gown of humility, with MENENIUS

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Here he comes, and in the gown of humility: mark his

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: behavior. We are not to stay all together, but to

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: come by him where he stands, by ones, by twos, and

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: by threes. He's to make his requests by

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: particulars; wherein every one of us has a single

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: honour, in giving him our own voices with our own

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: tongues: therefore follow me, and I direct you how

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: you shall go by him.

speaker: All
text_entry: Content, content.

speaker: All
text_entry: Exeunt Citizens

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: O sir, you are not right: have you not known

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: The worthiest men have done't?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What must I say?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: 'I Pray, sir'--Plague upon't! I cannot bring

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: My tongue to such a pace:--'Look, sir, my wounds!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I got them in my country's service, when

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Some certain of your brethren roar'd and ran

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: From the noise of our own drums.'

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: O me, the gods!

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: You must not speak of that: you must desire them

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: To think upon you.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Think upon me! hang 'em!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I would they would forget me, like the virtues

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Which our divines lose by 'em.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: You'll mar all:

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I'll leave you: pray you, speak to 'em, I pray you,

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: In wholesome manner.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Bid them wash their faces

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And keep their teeth clean.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Re-enter two of the Citizens

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: So, here comes a brace.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Re-enter a third Citizen

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You know the cause, air, of my standing here.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: We do, sir; tell us what hath brought you to't.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Mine own desert.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Your own desert!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Ay, but not mine own desire.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: How not your own desire?

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: No, sir,'twas never my desire yet to trouble the

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: poor with begging.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: You must think, if we give you any thing, we hope to

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: gain by you.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Well then, I pray, your price o' the consulship?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: The price is to ask it kindly.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Kindly! Sir, I pray, let me ha't: I have wounds to

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: show you, which shall be yours in private. Your

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: good voice, sir; what say you?

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: You shall ha' it, worthy sir.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: A match, sir. There's in all two worthy voices

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: begged. I have your alms: adieu.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: But this is something odd.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: An 'twere to give again,--but 'tis no matter.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Exeunt the three Citizens

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Re-enter two other Citizens

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Pray you now, if it may stand with the tune of your

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: voices that I may be consul, I have here the

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: customary gown.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: You have deserved nobly of your country, and you

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: have not deserved nobly.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Your enigma?

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: You have been a scourge to her enemies, you have

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: been a rod to her friends; you have not indeed loved

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: the common people.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: You should account me the more virtuous that I have

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: not been common in my love. I will, sir, flatter my

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: sworn brother, the people, to earn a dearer

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: estimation of them; 'tis a condition they account

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: gentle: and since the wisdom of their choice is

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: rather to have my hat than my heart, I will practise

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: the insinuating nod and be off to them most

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: counterfeitly; that is, sir, I will counterfeit the

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: bewitchment of some popular man and give it

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: bountiful to the desirers. Therefore, beseech you,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I may be consul.

speaker: Fifth Citizen
text_entry: We hope to find you our friend; and therefore give

speaker: Fifth Citizen
text_entry: you our voices heartily.

speaker: Fourth Citizen
text_entry: You have received many wounds for your country.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I will not seal your knowledge with showing them. I

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: will make much of your voices, and so trouble you no further.

speaker: Both Citizens
text_entry: The gods give you joy, sir, heartily!

speaker: Both Citizens
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Most sweet voices!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Better it is to die, better to starve,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Than crave the hire which first we do deserve.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Why in this woolvish toge should I stand here,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To beg of Hob and Dick, that do appear,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Their needless vouches? Custom calls me to't:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: What custom wills, in all things should we do't,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The dust on antique time would lie unswept,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: And mountainous error be too highly heapt

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: For truth to o'er-peer. Rather than fool it so,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Let the high office and the honour go

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: To one that would do thus. I am half through;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: The one part suffer'd, the other will I do.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Re-enter three Citizens more

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Here come more voices.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Your voices: for your voices I have fought;

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Watch'd for your voices; for Your voices bear

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Of wounds two dozen odd; battles thrice six

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: I have seen and heard of; for your voices have

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Done many things, some less, some more your voices:

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Indeed I would be consul.

speaker: Sixth Citizen
text_entry: He has done nobly, and cannot go without any honest

speaker: Sixth Citizen
text_entry: man's voice.

speaker: Seventh Citizen
text_entry: Therefore let him be consul: the gods give him joy,

speaker: Seventh Citizen
text_entry: and make him good friend to the people!

speaker: All Citizens
text_entry: Amen, amen. God save thee, noble consul!

speaker: All Citizens
text_entry: Exeunt

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Worthy voices!

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Re-enter MENENIUS, with BRUTUS and SICINIUS

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: You have stood your limitation; and the tribunes

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Endue you with the people's voice: remains

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: That, in the official marks invested, you

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: Anon do meet the senate.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Is this done?

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: The custom of request you have discharged:

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: The people do admit you, and are summon'd

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: To meet anon, upon your approbation.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Where? at the senate-house?

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: There, Coriolanus.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: May I change these garments?

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: You may, sir.

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: That I'll straight do; and, knowing myself again,

speaker: CORIOLANUS
text_entry: Repair to the senate-house.

speaker: MENENIUS
text_entry: I'll keep you company. Will you along?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We stay here for the people.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Fare you well.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Exeunt CORIOLANUS and MENENIUS

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: He has it now, and by his looks methink

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: 'Tis warm at 's heart.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With a proud heart he wore his humble weeds.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: will you dismiss the people?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Re-enter Citizens

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: How now, my masters! have you chose this man?

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: He has our voices, sir.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: We pray the gods he may deserve your loves.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Amen, sir: to my poor unworthy notice,

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: He mock'd us when he begg'd our voices.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Certainly

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: He flouted us downright.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: No,'tis his kind of speech: he did not mock us.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: Not one amongst us, save yourself, but says

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: He used us scornfully: he should have show'd us

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: His marks of merit, wounds received for's country.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Why, so he did, I am sure.

speaker: Citizens
text_entry: No, no; no man saw 'em.

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: He said he had wounds, which he could show

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: in private;

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: And with his hat, thus waving it in scorn,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: 'I would be consul,' says he: 'aged custom,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: But by your voices, will not so permit me;

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Your voices therefore.' When we granted that,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Here was 'I thank you for your voices: thank you:

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: Your most sweet voices: now you have left

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: your voices,

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: I have no further with you.' Was not this mockery?

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Why either were you ignorant to see't,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Or, seeing it, of such childish friendliness

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: To yield your voices?

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Could you not have told him

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As you were lesson'd, when he had no power,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: But was a petty servant to the state,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He was your enemy, ever spake against

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Your liberties and the charters that you bear

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: I' the body of the weal; and now, arriving

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A place of potency and sway o' the state,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If he should still malignantly remain

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Fast foe to the plebeii, your voices might

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Be curses to yourselves? You should have said

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That as his worthy deeds did claim no less

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than what he stood for, so his gracious nature

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Would think upon you for your voices and

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Translate his malice towards you into love,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Standing your friendly lord.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Thus to have said,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: As you were fore-advised, had touch'd his spirit

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: And tried his inclination; from him pluck'd

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Either his gracious promise, which you might,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: As cause had call'd you up, have held him to

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Or else it would have gall'd his surly nature,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Which easily endures not article

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Tying him to aught; so putting him to rage,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: You should have ta'en the advantage of his choler

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: And pass'd him unelected.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Did you perceive

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: He did solicit you in free contempt

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When he did need your loves, and do you think

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That his contempt shall not be bruising to you,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: When he hath power to crush? Why, had your bodies

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No heart among you? or had you tongues to cry

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Against the rectorship of judgment?

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Have you

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Ere now denied the asker? and now again

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Of him that did not ask, but mock, bestow

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Your sued-for tongues?

speaker: Third Citizen
text_entry: He's not confirm'd; we may deny him yet.

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: And will deny him:

speaker: Second Citizen
text_entry: I'll have five hundred voices of that sound.

speaker: First Citizen
text_entry: I twice five hundred and their friends to piece 'em.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Get you hence instantly, and tell those friends,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: They have chose a consul that will from them take

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Their liberties; make them of no more voice

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than dogs that are as often beat for barking

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: As therefore kept to do so.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Let them assemble,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: And on a safer judgment all revoke

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Your ignorant election; enforce his pride,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: And his old hate unto you; besides, forget not

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: With what contempt he wore the humble weed,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: How in his suit he scorn'd you; but your loves,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Thinking upon his services, took from you

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: The apprehension of his present portance,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Which most gibingly, ungravely, he did fashion

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: After the inveterate hate he bears you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Lay

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: A fault on us, your tribunes; that we laboured,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: No impediment between, but that you must

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Cast your election on him.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Say, you chose him

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: More after our commandment than as guided

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: By your own true affections, and that your minds,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Preoccupied with what you rather must do

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Than what you should, made you against the grain

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: To voice him consul: lay the fault on us.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Ay, spare us not. Say we read lectures to you.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How youngly he began to serve his country,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: How long continued, and what stock he springs of,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The noble house o' the Marcians, from whence came

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That Ancus Marcius, Numa's daughter's son,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Who, after great Hostilius, here was king;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Of the same house Publius and Quintus were,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: That our beat water brought by conduits hither;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And  [Censorinus,]  nobly named so,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Twice being  [by the people chosen]  censor,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Was his great ancestor.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: One thus descended,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: That hath beside well in his person wrought

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: To be set high in place, we did commend

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: To your remembrances: but you have found,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Scaling his present bearing with his past,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: That he's your fixed enemy, and revoke

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Your sudden approbation.

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Say, you ne'er had done't--

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Harp on that still--but by our putting on;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: And presently, when you have drawn your number,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Repair to the Capitol.

speaker: All
text_entry: We will so: almost all

speaker: All
text_entry: Repent in their election.

speaker: All
text_entry: Exeunt Citizens

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Let them go on;

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: This mutiny were better put in hazard,

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: Than stay, past doubt, for greater:

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: If, as his nature is, he fall in rage

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: With their refusal, both observe and answer

speaker: BRUTUS
text_entry: The vantage of his anger.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: To the Capitol, come:

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: We will be there before the stream o' the people;

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: And this shall seem, as partly 'tis, their own,

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Which we have goaded onward.

speaker: SICINIUS
text_entry: Exeunt
